title: Can airport security scanners detect gold items? - Quora

response.answer_text: Er, yeah. They use metal detectors. Gold is a metal. It’s the kind of thing metal detectors are specifically designed to detect. Unless you’re carrying a huge amount of it there’s really nothing to worry about. I’ve travelled with gold rings, gold cufflinks, my wife often has gold jewelry (rings, necklace etc). They show up on the scanner. The agent operating the scanner sees jewelry in the bag and it goes through the scanner for me to reclaim it. Unless you’re traveling to some tinpot banana republic where you’re afraid the agents are corrupt enough to demand you hand over your jewelry in exchange for safe passage (in which case you shouldn’t take gold items at all), the agents operating the security scanners don’t care if you’re travelling with personal effects that happen to be gold. If you’re travelling with $1,000,000 worth of gold bars that’s a different story. If you’ve got a legitimate reason to be carrying them you still won’t have anything to worry about. If that $1,000,000 worth of gold bars represents the proceeds of that month’s cocaine sales on the streets of London and you’re trying to fly to New York with it, be prepared to answer some awkward questions.

The metal detectors can easily detect gold, but they are usually calibrated to ignore small amounts—many people have gold fillings in their teeth, and would like to keep their glasses on while going through security, for example. The surface area of the metal seems to matter more than the actual amount of metal. When I lived in Germany, I flew Swissair a lot. On every flight, they offered the passengers chocolate. For several months, the chocolate was in the form of large, 10cm foil-wrapped coins. The flight attendants were adamant that you take lots of chocolate, so I always ended up with a few in my jacket pockets. They set off the security scanners every time! As a test, I ate the chocolate, but kept the foil crumpled up in a tight ball in the same pocket. The security scanners offered no warning after that. So: If you wish to smuggle gold, do so in small nuggets, rather than foil sheets.

It depends on how the scanners are set up. There are countries that are scanning their passages to see if they are carry gold on their person. Not sure how it is done here in the US. I went through the scanner once a few years ago with a gold coin in my pocket and nothing happened, but times have changed. On the X-ray machine for your hand luggage, the gold and silver will show up. They may ask you to open your bag to see what it is. If it is not over the limit for currency, you should not have any problems.

The latest terahertz body scanners (see www.thruvision.com) will also detect it if you are carrying anything in your pocket or strapped to your body.They will detect ANYTHING that you are concealing - not just metal.Drugs, currency, gems, nothing is invisible to them.The scanners are totally passive and can be easily concealed - you may not even know that you have been body scanned by one.

Yes they can. That is why you mix your gold coins in with your pocket change you put into the trays. I have always travelled with a 1oz silver coin in my wallet as it was one of the first things I bought with my own money. I also carry a single gold sovereign. I’ve never been stopped as it always goes in with my loose change.

I’m Manchester there are two types of scanners one detects any metal the other sends out wave lengths and will detect anything on your body so if wearing two layers of clothes or something attached to body it will detect it.
Definitely can. Gold is metal and airport security scanners are metal detectors and substance scanners, where gold will definitely stand out through both of them.
They detect any metal. That is why you have to take all nose rings, etc off. Bombs contain some kind of metal.
